sense.name: increase or cause to increase
sense.commentary: Syntax Includes: NP1[agent] DOUBLE NP2[patient] NP1[patient] DOUBLE PP NP1[patient] DOUBLE ADVP Includes: DOUBLE_UP
sense.examples: That stock has doubled in price over the past six months. They are doubling the security at the plant after last night's break in. We'll have to double our effort to finish this project on time.

sense.name: a two-base hit in baseball
sense.examples: Johnny doubled on his first time at bat. The runner might have doubled if he hadn't stalled at first base. The runner doubled due to an error by the shortstop.

sense.name: physically bend over or curl up
sense.commentary: Syntax Is: NP1[patient] DOUBLE PP Includes: DOUBLE_OVER, DOUBLE_UP
sense.examples: The boy doubled in pain as the bullet struck him. That comedy will have you doubling over with laughter. I had to sort of double up to ride in the back of John's small car.

sense.name: to function in two different roles or capacities
sense.commentary: Syntax Includes: NP1[instrument] DOUBLE NP2[attribute] (and NP3[attribute]) NP1[actor[plural]] DOUBLE NP2[attribute] (and NP3[attribute]) Includes: DOUBLE_UP
sense.examples: Mary doubles as the secretary and the treasurer of our club. This pouch could double as my purse and a small suitcase. Mary and I doubled up in one room because the hotel was already full.

sense.name: to make a bid or call in contract bridge
sense.commentary: Syntax Is: NP[agent] DOUBLE NP[patient] Note: patient is always cards
sense.examples: Mary said 'I double hearts' to the bridge players at her table.

sense.name: to replicate or reproduce something
sense.examples: Who could ever double the fantastic season the Red Sox had in 2004? I've tried to double my grandmother's homemade biscuits, but they just aren't the same.
